title: ‘Cri, Cri’… a Jar Full of Crickets. Building a Multi-Factor Climate Risk Index for Fossil Fuels and ESG Investments
affiliations: Universidad Complutense de Madrid (UCM) and Universidad Complutense de Madrid (UCM) - Faculty of Economics and Business Administration

detail.title: ‘Cri, Cri’… a Jar Full of Crickets. Building a Multi-Factor Climate Risk Index for Fossil Fuels and ESG Investments
detail.abstract: This paper introduces a novel multi-factor Climate Risk Index (CRI) designed to better capture the multifaceted nature of climate change risks and their implications for economic and financial markets, with a particular focus on energy and ESG investments. We construct different CRIs that consider climate risk components from established indices across three crucial information sources: climate change news sentiment, physical climate impacts, and climate policy developments. We employ robust multi-stage dimensionality reduction and modeling approaches, including Principal Components Analysis (PCA) for initial extraction, feature engineering, and consolidation of climate risk signals; t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE) for further, non-linear dimension reduction; and Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR) to integrate market response variables, and develop dedicated, ad-hoc CRIs specifically tailored for fossil fuels and ESG investments. We also develop a "super-CRI" by applying a meta-combination technique, the Wavelets Ensemble (METS 3.0), to synthesize diverse climate risk indicators into one comprehensive measure. Our CRI alternatives offer a significant step forward for understanding and pricing climate risk in financial assets.

title: Intelligent Assessment Method of Progressive Collapse Resistance of Corroded Latticed Shell Structures Considering Time-Varying Effect
affiliations: Hohai University, Hohai University, Southeast University and Hohai University

detail.title: Intelligent Assessment Method of Progressive Collapse Resistance of Corroded Latticed Shell Structures Considering Time-Varying Effect
detail.abstract: Single-layer latticed shells feature high load-transfer efficiency and flexible modeling, making them a commonly used roof structure form in large public buildings such as gymnasiums and airport terminals. However, in recent years, accidents of progressive collapse of roof structures have occurred frequently, and the corrosion problem of structures during long-term service is one of the main causes of such accidents. This paper takes the K8-type spherical latticed shell as the research object, considers the time-varying effect of corrosion, simulates corrosion by reducing the section thickness, and uses the alternative load path method to carry out numerical simulation on the collapse process of the latticed shell. The verified numerical simulation method is used to carry out the parametric analysis of the anti-progressive collapse performance of the corroded latticed shell. The results show that the anti-progressive collapse performance of the latticed shell decreases with the increase of service time, and shows the law of first decreasing and then tending to be stable with the increase of the corrosion area. The position of the initial failure node, the geometric size of the latticed shell and the form of load distribution all have significant effects on the degradation degree of the anti-collapse performance of the latticed shell. On this basis, the data set of the deep feedforward neural network is generated, and the intelligent evaluation model of the anti-progressive collapse performance of the corroded latticed shell is established, which can accurately and efficiently predict the anti-progressive collapse performance of the corroded latticed shell.

title: Prediction of Pipeline Strain Demand Under Ground Movement Using a Neural Network–Enhanced Finite Difference Method
affiliations: University of Alberta, University of Alberta, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Alberta

detail.title: Prediction of Pipeline Strain Demand Under Ground Movement Using a Neural Network–Enhanced Finite Difference Method
detail.abstract: Pipelines are vulnerable to permanent ground movement induced by geohazards, which can lead to excessive strain and potential structural failure. Accurate prediction of strain demand is essential for ensuring pipeline safety and supporting geohazard risk assessment. A recently developed finite difference method (FDM)-based framework for pipeline strain analysis has demonstrated strong potential as a fast and practical tool. However, the current framework relies on a bilinear stress–strain assumption, which allows closed-form expressions for axial force and bending moment in the governing equations. With more general nonlinear hardening models, such expressions are no longer available, and internal forces must instead be evaluated through numerical integration. This leads to a substantial increase in computational cost. To address this limitation, this study proposes a neural network–enhanced finite difference method (NN-FDM). This approach augments the original FDM by incorporating neural network surrogate models that replace numerical integration for internal force evaluation, thereby enabling the inclusion of general nonlinear hardening behavior within the finite difference framework. Two case studies are conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method under both bilinear and nonlinear hardening conditions. Results demonstrate that NN-FDM achieves high accuracy while significantly improving computational efficiency in the presence of nonlinear hardening behavior. The proposed method provides a simple and general framework for evaluating pipeline strain demand across a wide range of constitutive models and shows strong potential as an efficient tool for rapid assessment and pre-screening applications in geohazard-prone areas.

title: Security Against Eavesdropping and Traffic Analysis Attacks in Automation Networks
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Security Against Eavesdropping and Traffic Analysis Attacks in Automation Networks
detail.abstract: Recently, a new security strategy against eavesdropping attacks in Cyber-Physical Systems abstracted as Discrete-Event Systems has been proposed in the literature. The new security scheme leads to reduced communication delays, which makes it suitable for application in automation networks. This scheme has been called event-based cryptography, where an event is defined as any change in the binary signals transmitted in the network. Although encryption can prevent an attacker from understanding which events have been transmitted, it is not sufficient to ensure system confidentiality. This is due to the fact that, in some cases, the pattern of event occurrences can be used to distinguish events or even identifying which event has occurred. This type of attack is called traffic analysis attack. In this paper, we propose the use of a padding mechanism together with the event-based cryptography, to prevent intruders from performing traffic analysis attacks. The event-padding mechanism inserts encrypted fake events to mascarade the time pattern of the system. A feasibility analysis of the proposed security scheme in a real application example is presented.

title: Technological Transition Frictions and Price Discovery: Evidence from the Sec's Https Mandate
affiliations: ESADE Business School and Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona

detail.title: Technological Transition Frictions and Price Discovery: Evidence from the Sec's Https Mandate
detail.abstract: The increasing integration of modern information technologies into policies promoting market efficiency raises persistent concerns about the technological transition costs they impose on market participants. This study provides novel direct evidence of the existence of such costs and causally identifies their consequences for price discovery. Our unique empirical setting is the Securities and Exchange Commission’s 2016 adoption of a more secure data communication protocol for its online repository of corporate disclosures. During the first year of implementation, some users failed to adapt to the new protocol, which prevented them from accessing electronic filings and disrupted the processing of company disclosures. We show that these technological frictions reduced price informativeness for firms publishing new reports, consistent with the idea that higher information acquisition costs diverted resources necessary for interpreting the filings. Supporting this mechanism, we demonstrate that transition costs also undermined informed trading activity. We further explore heterogeneity and find that the negative impact of technological barriers is less pronounced when users were more sophisticated, when firms concurrently announced earnings, and when reports were less complex. Our results highlight that technological transition frictions are a first-order  concern for policymakers and underscore the critical need to manage them within regulatory frameworks.

title: The Performance Puzzle in Venture Capital and Private Equity Style Drifts
affiliations: Florida Atlantic University - Finance, SKEMA Business School  and Gonzaga University - School of Business Administration

detail.title: The Performance Puzzle in Venture Capital and Private Equity Style Drifts
detail.abstract: Previous studies reveal conflicting results on how style drift affects performance in venture capital and private equity. This paper identifies a key factor behind these inconsistencies: the distinction between initial style drift (first-time investments) and follow-on style drift (subsequent investments in the same company). We propose that follow-on style drift exacerbates escalation of commitment, adversely impacting performance. Our large sample analysis shows initial style drift is associated with positive exit performance, while the follow-on style drift has poorer outcomes. We discuss the implications and suggest directions for future research.

title: Renewable Energy Communities in Central Africa: Towards a Hybrid Model, Tariff Impacts, Energy Justice and Local Governance

detail.title: Renewable Energy Communities in Central Africa: Towards a Hybrid Model, Tariff Impacts, Energy Justice and Local Governance

keywords.keywords: Renewable Energy Communities  Hybrid Energy Systems

detail.abstract: A B S T R A C TRenewable Energy Hybrid Communities (RECs) represent a promising solution to address energy poverty, climate change and urban resilience in Central Africa. This study assesses the economic viability and equity implications of deploying hybrid energy systems combining solar, wind and biomass in Cameroon's urban neighbourhoods. Using a discounted cash flow approach and net present value (NPV) as the main indicator, the research simulates several scenarios influenced by self consumption rates, government subsidies, and investment costs. The results show that PV-based RECs become profitable from 30% self-consumption, with NPVs ranging from €4100/kW in low-support scenarios to more than €10,000/kW in high-support conditions. The levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) has been estimated at between €102 and €125/MWh, confirming a strong competitiveness compared to regional grid tariffs.The study also introduces two innovative benefit-sharing models. One incentivizes virtuous energy behavior through competitive exchange pricing (PDM3), while the other prioritizes energy equity by allocating greater benefits to lower-income households (PDM4). Both models reduce disparities between prosumers and enable inclusive participation without sacrificing financial returns. Additionally, the inclusion of non-producing consumers in RECs highlights the potential for broader social integration, although it necessitates careful regulation to avoid benefit dilution.

title: Transportation Optimization for Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage Technology Adoption in Major Carbon-Emitting Industries in China Under the Carbon Neutrality Goal
affiliations: Tsinghua University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Transportation Optimization for Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage Technology Adoption in Major Carbon-Emitting Industries in China Under the Carbon Neutrality Goal
detail.abstract: Driven by the global carbon neutrality goal, China must accelerate the development of Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) technologies to address emission reduction needs in high-carbon industries like coal power, steel, cement, and modern coal chemicals. This study constructs an operational optimization model to plan a cost-minimizing pipeline network for the entire CCUS process, from capture and transportation to storage. It incorporates diverse storage sites, including depleted oil and gas fields, un-mineable coal seams, and deep saline aquifers, and evaluates the spatial matching and economic feasibility of CCUS deployment under two scenarios: annual CO2 reductions of 1.062 billion tons and 1.439 billion tons. The results show that the 1.062 billion ton scenario requires 552 pipelines spanning 22,168 kilometers, while the 1.439 billion ton scenario needs 611 pipelines covering 23,795 kilometers, primarily concentrated in Northwest, North, and Northeast China. Source-sink combinations involving modern coal chemicals and depleted oilfields exhibit superior economic performance, making them ideal for prioritized full-process demonstrations. Key regions for demonstration projects include Hami (Xinjiang), Yulin (Shaanxi), Changji (Xinjiang), Daqing (Heilongjiang), and Yinchuan (Ningxia), which offer abundant emission sources, favorable storage conditions, and short transportation distances. This study provides critical insights for national CCUS planning, recommending large-scale demonstrations in advantageous regions to achieve cost reductions and industry chain development through policy support, technological innovation, and industrial collaboration, thereby supporting China’s carbon neutrality goal.

title: Stacked Ensemble Learning with Shap-Prioritized Intervention Ranking for Pavement Maintenance Automation
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Stacked Ensemble Learning with Shap-Prioritized Intervention Ranking for Pavement Maintenance Automation
detail.abstract: This study presents an automated decision-support framework for pavement maintenance and rehabilitation (M&R) prioritization using machine learning and explainable AI. A stacked ensemble classifier—combining tuned LightGBM, ExtraTrees, SVM, and MLP as base learners with XGBoost as the meta-learner—was developed using nine pavement condition indicators. The model predicts discrete M&R classes with high accuracy (98.3%), macro F1-score (0.98), precision (0.98), and recall (0.98). Model transparency was achieved through SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), which identified Current MSA, Roughness IRI, and Structural Number as dominant predictors. A SHAP-informed composite scoring system enabled intra-class prioritization of road segments into Urgent, Medium, and Low categories. Sensitivity analysis confirmed that rankings for urgent interventions remained stable under ±20% feature weight variations. The framework offers a robust, interpretable, and scalable tool for network-level pavement management, supporting data-driven intervention planning with improved transparency and objectivity.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization of Process Industrial Energy Systems Containing Hydrogen Energy
affiliations: Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming University of Science and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Kunming University of Science and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming University of Science and Technology and Kunming University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Multi-Objective Optimization of Process Industrial Energy Systems Containing Hydrogen Energy
detail.abstract: Iron and steel industry is an important pillar of global economic development, and its high production volume is accompanied by a large amount of energy consumption and carbon emissions. In order to improve the energy efficiency, carbon efficiency and economy of the steel process system, this paper establishes an optimization model for the integrated energy system (IES) of an iron and steel industrial park considering multifunctional hydrogen production and carbon capture equipment, starting from the steel production system and the energy system, and with the objective of minimizing the total cost of the system and maximizing the energy utilization rate. Five cases were set up for comparative analysis and solved using the -constraint method. The optimization results show that the iron and steel production process is optimized by introducing hydrogen production from electricity and by-product gas in the iron and steel industrial park. Compared with the unoptimized system, after considering the carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology and the stepped carbon trading mechanism, the energy utilization rate is increased by 17.36%, the carbon emission of the park is reduced by 12504.36 t, and the total cost of the system is reduced by 12.31%, while meeting the demand of the energy load of the park. The experimental results show that the proposed model effectively improves the energy utilization while ensuring the reduction of economic cost, and the synergistic optimization of carbon capture and hydrogen energy system further reduces the carbon emission. These results provide guidance for energy efficiency and low-carbon economic operations in the steel industry.

title: Toward Sustainable Manufacturing: Robust Bilevel Optimization of Photovoltaic-Thermal Systems with Integrated Energy Storage Under Demand Response
affiliations: University of Illinois Chicago, University of Illinois Chicago and University of Illinois at Chicago

detail.title: Toward Sustainable Manufacturing: Robust Bilevel Optimization of Photovoltaic-Thermal Systems with Integrated Energy Storage Under Demand Response
detail.abstract: The manufacturing sector is a major contributor to global energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions, underscoring the need for on-site renewable energy integration to reduce fossil fuel dependence and advance sustainable manufacturing. Among renewable energy technologies, Photovoltaic-Thermal (PVT) systems offer a promising solution by simultaneously generating electricity and thermal energy. Their integrations with Battery Energy Storage (BES), Thermal Energy Storage (TES), and Demand Response (DR) programs enhance the economic viability of such systems and the sustainability of manufacturing activities. This paper develops an optimization framework that combines bilevel and robust optimization to jointly optimize system configuration and operational scheduling for a PVT-BES-TES system in manufacturing facilities, considering weather uncertainties that influence PVT generation. The bilevel optimization model is formulated as a Mixed-Integer Nonlinear Programming (MINLP) problem, while the robust optimization approach employs polyhedral uncertainty sets with bounded intervals for solar irradiance and ambient temperature, ensuring solution feasibility under worst-case scenarios. A case study on a lithium-ion battery manufacturing facility was conducted to evaluate the economic and environmental benefits of integrating a PVT-BES-TES system under the DR program. Compared to the baseline scenario without PVT and DR integration, the proposed configuration achieves a 26.08% reduction in total annualized costs and a 14.35% decrease in total CO2 emissions. These findings underscore the economic and environmental advantages of PVT adoption in industrial settings under DR programs, demonstrating its potential to enhance energy flexibility and support sustainable manufacturing.

title: Capacity Investment and Leasing of Shared Energy Storage Systems Under Uncertainty
affiliations: National University of Singapore (NUS) - Department of Industrial & Systems Engineering, affiliation not provided to SSRN, National University of Singapore (NUS) - NUS Environmental Research Institute (NERI) and National University of Singapore (NUS) - Energy Studies Institute

detail.title: Capacity Investment and Leasing of Shared Energy Storage Systems Under Uncertainty
detail.abstract: We investigate optimal investment and leasing strategies for Shared Energy Storage(SES) systems under energy demand and supply uncertainty. A bi-level optimizationframework is proposed, where the operator decides on storage capacity and pricing,and tenants respond with rental bids and usage schedules. We introduce capacityquota allocations to improve capacity utilisation when storage size options are discrete,and show closed-form tenant bidding strategies under constant tariffs. In thegeneral case we propose a scalable solution method based on a variable discretizationand avoiding complex Karush–Kuhn–Tucker (KKT) conditions. Results demonstratesignificant improvements in capacity utilization and cost recovery, highlighting theSES model’s potential to enhance renewable integration and economic efficiency incommunity energy systems.

title: Panet: Physics And Action Informed Network for Water Level Prediction
affiliations: China Institute of Water Resources and Hydropower Research (IWHR) - State Key Laboratory of Simulation and Regulation of Water Cycle in River Basin, Hebei University of Engineering, Hebei University of Engineering, Hebei University of Engineering, Hebei University of Engineering and Hebei University of Engineering

detail.title: Panet: Physics And Action Informed Network for Water Level Prediction
detail.abstract: Accurate water level prediction in inter-basin water transfer projects is essential for scientifically formulating scheduling decisions and ensuring the operational safety of water conveyance systems. Though traditional hydrodynamic models offer strong physical interpretability, they face significant limitations in parameter acquisition and adaptability to complex hydraulic conditions. Conversely, deep learning-based prediction methods exhibit robust generalization capabilities, but suffer from limited interpretability, particularly concerning the simultaneous modeling of hydrological delays and Markovian properties. Furthermore, these methods struggle to elucidate the intrinsic relationship between human-regulated control operations and hydraulic responses. To address above challenges, this study proposes PANet (Physics- and Action-informed water prediction Network), a multi-step water level prediction model. PANet innovatively integrates Integral Delay (ID) theory as its underlying physical mechanism with action-informed structures, enabling the simultaneous modeling of hydrological delays, Markovian properties, and the causal relationship between operational interventions and hydraulic responses. Specifically, it comprises two key components: the Action Attention Encoder (A2E) and the Dual-branch Decoder (DBD). The A2E utilizes operational signals such as gate openings to enhance sensitivity to anthropogenic interventions, while the DBD captures both short-term hydraulic dynamics and long-term water level evolution, thereby improving predictive performance across multiple temporal scales. Extensive experimental results on the multi-reach segments of the Middle Route of the South-to-North Water Diversion Project demonstrate that PANet achieves superior accuracy and stability in multi-step water level prediction tasks compared to state-of-the-art deep learning approaches.

title: From Playgrounds to Portfolios: How Relative Age Shapes Financial Advisor Misconduct
affiliations: Shenzhen University, Monash Business School and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: From Playgrounds to Portfolios: How Relative Age Shapes Financial Advisor Misconduct
detail.abstract: This paper shows that financial advisors (FAs) who are relatively older within their kindergarten cohorts exhibit a higher likelihood of professional misconduct later in their careers. This effect is more pronounced in firms with stronger peer pressure and weaker ethical norms. Our findings remain robust when controlling for omitted variable bias, selection bias, and a range of robustness checks. We provide new evidence that early-life developmental factors play a significant role in shaping ethical decision-making within financial professions.

title: Better Late than Never: Environmental Punishments and Corporate Green Hiring
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology and Huazhong University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Better Late than Never: Environmental Punishments and Corporate Green Hiring
detail.abstract: Do firms adjust their hiring decisions after receiving environmental punishments? Using data on over 4.3 million job postings for Chinese listed firms from 2015 to 2021, we find that firms subjected to environmental punishments will subsequently increase their corporate green hiring (i.e., employees with green skills). Pressure from local environmental concerns and regulatory efforts incentivizes firms to increase their demand for employees with green skills. Environmental punishments have a more pronounced effect on corporate green hiring for non-state-owned enterprises and firms with lower financial constraints. Moreover, green hiring can have a remediation effect on firms’ environmental performance and stimulate their green innovation activities and spillover effects on other firms within the industry. Overall, our findings shed light on corporate hiring decisions under environmental regulations.

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation for Singular Wishart Distribution

detail.title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation for Singular Wishart Distribution
detail.abstract: This paper considers the Bartlett decomposition for a singular Wishart variable, to derive the log-expectation. A re-parameterization for maximum likelihood estimation is proposed to separately estimate the scale matrix and the degrees-of-freedom parameter. Its asymptotic properties are analyzed.
